p.s: Description of Leptolinea tardivitalis sp. nov.
Leptolinea tardivitalis (tar.di.vi.ta′lis. L. adj. tardus slow; L. fem. adj. vitalis vital, alive; N.L. fem. adj. tardivitalis having a slow lifestyle).
Multicellular filaments are longer than 100 μm and thinner than 0.2 μm.
Growth occurs between 25 and 50 °C with optimum growth at 37 °C.
Growth is observed at pH 6.0–7.2 with optimum growth at pH 7.0.
Doubling time for growth is 50 h under optimal growth conditions.
In the presence of 0.01 % yeast extract, growth is observed with glucose, mannose, fructose, xylose, ribose, sucrose, raffinose, xylan, pectin, tryptone and betaine.
Weak growth occurs with the following substrates with medium supplemented with 0.01 % yeast extract: Casamino acids, peptone, galactose, arabinose, starch and pyruvate.

The following substrate are not utilized in the presence of 0.01 % yeast extract: crotonate, H2/CO2 plus acetate, lactate, glycerol, fumarate, acetate, propionate, butyrate, malate, succinate, ethanol, methanol, 1-propanol, ethylene glycol, hydroquinone, phenol, benzoate and formate plus acetate.
Sulphate, sulphite, thiosulphate, elemental sulphur, nitrate, fumarate and Fe(III)-NTA are not utilized as electron acceptors.

The type strain is strain YMTK-2T (=JCM 12579T=DSM 16556T), isolated from sludge in a mesophilic UASB reactor in which an artificial wastewater composed mainly of peptone, sucrose, propionate and acetate is treated.
